entry.title: Intel Needs a Big Customer for Foundry Business to Survive
entry.content:
Max A. Cherney and Stephen Nellis, reporting for Reuters:

Those customers for the company‚Äôs so-called 14A manufacturing process are crucial to the success of the technology - so much so that if it fails to secure a big one, it could shut down its cutting-edge manufacturing business altogether, according to Intel‚Äôs quarterly filing on Thursday.

The possibility that Intel could drop out of the cutting-edge manufacturing business would be a historic shift for a company that has described itself as a steward of Moore‚Äôs Law - an observation by Intel co-founder Gordon Moore about the fast rate of development of the chip industry that held true for decades. Intel is the only U.S. chipmaker capable of making advanced computing chips.

Intel has struggled for years due to management missteps, missing out on the AI race and losing market share to its longtime rival AMD.

The beginning of the end for Intel was long before the AI race or the market share they‚Äôve lost to AMD. It was missing out on mobile. From a 2013 profile of then-CEO Paul Ortellini, by Alexis Madrigal for The Atlantic:

But, oh, what could have been! Even Otellini betrayed a profound sense of disappointment over a decision he made about a then-unreleased product that became the iPhone. Shortly after winning Apple‚Äôs Mac business, he decided against doing what it took to be the chip in Apple‚Äôs paradigm-shifting product.

‚ÄúWe ended up not winning it or passing on it, depending on how you want to view it. And the world would have been a lot different if we‚Äôd done it,‚Äù Otellini told me in a two-hour conversation during his last month at Intel. ‚ÄúThe thing you have to remember is that this was before the iPhone was introduced and no one knew what the iPhone would do... At the end of the day, there was a chip that they were interested in that they wanted to pay a certain price for and not a nickel more and that price was below our forecasted cost. I couldn‚Äôt see it. It wasn‚Äôt one of these things you can make up on volume. And in hindsight, the forecasted cost was wrong and the volume was 100√ó what anyone thought.‚Äù

That was it, the beginning of the end. It‚Äôs not just that mobile computing, as defined by the iPhone, became the largest market, by far, for chips, but that the needs of mobile devices defined the future of leading edge chipmaking across all industries: performance-per-watt, not merely sheer performance. As mobile grew, so went the economies of scale, which resulted in Apple Silicon eventually beating x86 chips not just in performance-per-watt but also in single-core performance.

entry.title: goo.gl, Google‚Äôs Link Shortener, Will Stop Working Next Month
entry.content:
Emma Roth, The Verge:

Google will officially deprecate links generated with its URL shortening tool next month. On August 25th, 2025, all links in the https://goo.gl/* format will no longer work and return a 404 error message.

Google shut down its URL shortener in 2019, citing ‚Äúchanges we‚Äôve seen in how people find content on the internet.‚Äù Links created with the tool continued to work since then, but Google announced last year that it would begin deprecating them as traffic to the shortened URLs declined. ‚ÄúIn fact more than 99% of them had no activity in the last month,‚Äù Google said in its July 2024 blog post.

The heyday for link shorteners was the era when Twitter (a) was still Twitter, (b) had a 140-character post limit, and (c) each character of a URL you tweeted counted toward that character limit. None of those things are true anymore. But, still. Cool URLs don‚Äôt change.

I‚Äôm sure it is true that 99 percent of goo.gl links had no activity in the past month. But I‚Äôm just as sure that it would cost next to nothing for Google to keep goo.gl up and running in perpetuity. I mean, 99 percent of all URLs probably had no activity in the last month. 99 percent of all books ever written weren‚Äôt read in the last month either, I bet‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut that‚Äôs no excuse for libraries to throw them in the trash.

It‚Äôs fine that Google stopped allowing for the creating of new links a while back, but there‚Äôs no reason they should ever stop redirecting existing links. The whole reason anyone might have used goo.gl instead of something like bit.ly is misplaced trust in Google. I trust Google with almost nothing long-term. Mark my words, they‚Äôre going to do this with Gmail accounts eventually.

entry.summary: To maintain anonymity and store zero user data, there is and can be no web app version of ICEBlock. There is and can be no Android version. Only iOS supports the security and privacy features for ICEBlock to offer what it does, the way it does.
entry.content:
ICEBlock:

ICEBlock is an innovative, completely anonymous crowdsourced platform that allows users to report Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) activity with just two taps on their phone. In recent years, ICE has faced criticism for alleged civil rights abuses and failures to adhere to constitutional principles and due process, making it crucial for communities to stay informed about its operations.

Modeled after Waze but for ICE sightings, the app ensures user privacy by storing no personal data, making it impossible to trace reports back to individual users. Available exclusively for iOS devices, ICEBlock empowers communities to stay informed about ICE presence within a 5-mile radius while maintaining their anonymity through real-time updates and automatic deletion of sightings after four hours.

The ICEBlock app is interesting in and of itself (and from my tire-kicking test drive, appears to be a well-crafted and designed app), as will be Apple‚Äôs response if (when?) the Trump administration takes offense to the app‚Äôs existence. Back in 2019, kowtowing to tacit demands from China, Apple removed from the App Store an app called HKmap.live which helped pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong know the location of police and protest activity. The app broke no Hong Kong laws, but scared the thin-skinned skittish lickspittles in the Chinese Communist Party. (Remember too that in 2019, Apple removed the Taiwan flag emoji (üáπüáº) from the iOS 13 keyboard for users in Hong Kong and Macau.)

One defense from Apple regarding HKmap.live, however, was that the iOS app was a thin wrapper around the website, which website remained fully functional and could be saved to an iPhone user‚Äôs home screen. Removing the app from the App Store thus did not prevent Hong Kongers from accessing it. (That website today seems to be defunct.)

ICEBlock is different. It is only available as a native iOS app. According to the developers, this is for technical reasons. From their web page explaining why they can‚Äôt offer an Android version:

At ICEBlock, user privacy and security are paramount. Our application is designed to provide as much anonymity as possible without storing any user data or creating accounts. While we understand the desire for an Android version of ICEBlock, achieving this level of anonymity on Android is not feasible due to the inherent requirements of push notification services.

To send push notifications on Android, it is necessary to use a mechanism that requires storing device IDs. This means that we would need to maintain a privately hosted database to store these identifiers. Storing such data, even if it‚Äôs anonymized, introduces significant privacy risks. [...]

In contrast, iOS offers us the flexibility to deliver push notifications while adhering strictly to our design philosophy. Apple‚Äôs ecosystem allows for push notifications to be sent without requiring us to store any user-identifiable information. This ensures that ICEBlock remains completely anonymous and secure.

To deliver push notifications on Android, the developers claim they would need to maintain a database of device IDs, create a user account system to manage those device IDs, and all of that server-stored data would be susceptible to law enforcement subpoenas and pro-ICE red hat hackers. (What ‚Äúbrown shirts‚Äù were to the Nazis, we should make ‚Äúred hats‚Äù to MAGA.)

To maintain anonymity and store zero user data, there is and can be no web app version of ICEBlock. There is and can be no Android version. Only iOS supports the security and privacy features for ICEBlock to offer what it does, the way it does. Here‚Äôs to hoping that Apple will proudly defend it if push comes to shove.

entry.title: The Financial Times Reports the UK Is Backing Down From Its Demand for Apple to Grant It an iCloud Encryption Backdoor
entry.content:
Anna Gross, Tim Bradshaw, and Lauren Fedor, reporting for the Financial Times (syndicated without paywall at Ars Technica):

Sir Keir Starmer‚Äôs government is seeking a way out of a clash with the Trump administration over the UK‚Äôs demand that Apple provide it with access to secure customer data, two senior British officials have told the Financial Times. The officials both said the Home Office, which ordered the tech giant in January to grant access to its most secure cloud storage system, would probably have to retreat in the face of pressure from senior leaders in Washington, including Vice President JD Vance.

‚ÄúThis is something that the vice president is very annoyed about and which needs to be resolved,‚Äù said an official in the UK‚Äôs technology department. ‚ÄúThe Home Office is basically going to have to back down.‚Äù

Both officials said the UK decision to force Apple to break its end-to-end encryption‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich has been raised multiple times by top officials in Donald Trump‚Äôs administration‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâcould impede technology agreements with the US.

‚ÄúOne of the challenges for the tech partnerships we‚Äôre working on is the encryption issue,‚Äù the first official said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a big red line in the US‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthey don‚Äôt want us messing with their tech companies.‚Äù

One dystopian element of the UK‚Äôs Investigatory Powers Act is that when companies are issued demands under the law‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich critics in the UK call ‚Äúthe Snoopers‚Äô Charter‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit‚Äôs a criminal offense subject to imprisonment to reveal to anyone that the UK government issued the demand. You will recall that after receiving this demand, in February this year Apple pulled iCloud Advanced Data Protection from users in the UK.

What I don‚Äôt like about the Financial Times‚Äôs framing of this is that they describe it only in terms of politics between the Trump administration and Starmer‚Äôs. This is not merely about a foreign government ‚Äúmessing with their tech companies‚Äù. It‚Äôs fundamentally about privacy and security. It is a human rights and civil liberties issue, first and foremost. The Trump administration is on the correct and just side of this issue. Whether they‚Äôre on the correct side for the right reasons, I don‚Äôt know, but that‚Äôs what‚Äôs most important here. A secret backdoor is abhorrent from all perspectives: privacy, security, civil liberties. (Not to mention impossible cryptographically with E2EE‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâmandating a backdoor is effectively banning E2EE, which is why Apple pulled Advanced Data Protection from the UK.)

Conversely, one reason the UK went through with this demand is that the Biden administration was, disgracefully, on the wrong side of this, choosing to look the other way and lie to Congress about what the UK was planning to do.

Ellen Nakashima, Yvonne Wingett Sanchez and Joseph Menn, reporting for The Washington Post:

Tens of thousands of such servers are at risk, experts said, and Microsoft has issued no patch for the flaw, leaving victims around the world scrambling to respond.

The ‚Äúzero-day‚Äù attack, so called because it targeted a previously unknown vulnerability, is only the latest cybersecurity embarrassment for Microsoft. Last year, the company was faulted by a panel of U.S. government and industry experts for lapses that enabled a 2023 targeted Chinese hack of U.S. government emails, including those of then-Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo.

This most recent attack compromises only those servers housed within an organization‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânot those in the cloud, such as Microsoft 365, officials said. After first suggesting that users make modifications to or simply unplug SharePoint server programs from the internet, the company on Sunday evening released a patch for one version of the software. Two other versions remain vulnerable and Microsoft said it is continuing to work to develop a patch.

‚ÄúJust pull the plug‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâclassic Microsoft security.

With access to these servers, which often connect to Outlook email, Teams and other core services, a breach can lead to theft of sensitive data as well as password harvesting, Netherlands-based research company Eye Security noted. What‚Äôs also alarming, researchers said, is that the hackers have gained access to keys that may allow them to regain entry even after a system is patched. ‚ÄúSo pushing out a patch on Monday or Tuesday doesn‚Äôt help anybody who‚Äôs been compromised in the past 72 hours,‚Äù said one researcher, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because a federal investigation is ongoing.

Sounds bad.

The nonprofit Center for Internet Security, which staffs an information-sharing group for state and local governments, notified about 100 organizations that they were vulnerable and potentially compromised, said Randy Rose, the organization‚Äôs vice president. Those warned included public schools and universities. The process took six hours Saturday night‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâmuch longer than it otherwise would have, because the threat-intelligence and incident-response teams have been cut by 65 percent as CISA slashed funding, Rose said.

One woman described arriving at Krome‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa facility that typically only holds men‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâlate at night on January 28. Staff were dismissive or abusive even when detainees were undergoing a visibly obvious medical crisis. For example, staff ignored a detained immigrant who began coughing blood in a crowded holding cell for hours. A detainee said he heard an officer order the cell‚Äôs CCTV camera feed to be turned off. Another detainee said a team member slapped him while shouting, ‚ÄúShut the fuck up.‚Äù

entry.title: Don‚Äôt Forget About Atari

Cory Ondrejka joins in on the 40-year-old retro computing reminiscing:

For being otherwise bright folks, it‚Äôs remarkable how completely wrong they all are. The Atari was the best computer to have.

In 1985 Tramiel launched the Atari ST line at CES. To me the 16-bit Atari ST barely registers in my memory‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI don‚Äôt think I ever encountered one anywhere, including in a store. When I think of Atari personal computers I think of the 8-bit Atari 800 (pretty cool!) and 400 (horrible‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâperhaps the worst keyboard ever shipped) from 1979.

entry.summary: Why CBS‚Äôs cancellation of ‚ÄúThe Late Show With Stephen Colbert‚Äù stinks to high hell.
entry.content:
Why CBS‚Äôs Cancellation of ‚ÄúThe Late Show With Stephen Colbert‚Äù Stinks to High Hell

Even back in the now-comparatively-sane Trump 1.0 administration, it seemed palpably true to me that the best check against Trump‚Äôs authoritarian instincts wasn‚Äôt legal or Constitutional, but rather cultural. The culture of free speech, of being able to criticize‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâin no uncertain terms, with no held punches‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâanyone in authority is fundamental to the American mindset. It‚Äôs like the opening of David Foster Wallace‚Äôs ‚ÄúThis Is Water‚Äù 2005 commencement address to Kenyon College:

Greetings parents and congratulations to Kenyon‚Äôs graduating class of 2005. There are these two young fish swimming along and they happen to meet an older fish swimming the other way, who nods at them and says ‚ÄúMorning, boys. How‚Äôs the water?‚Äù And the two young fish swim on for a bit, and then eventually one of them looks over at the other and goes ‚ÄúWhat the hell is water?‚Äù

This is a standard requirement of US commencement speeches, the deployment of didactic little parable-ish stories. The story thing turns out to be one of the better, less bullshitty conventions of the genre, but if you‚Äôre worried that I plan to present myself here as the wise, older fish explaining what water is to you younger fish, please don‚Äôt be. I am not the wise old fish. The point of the fish story is merely that the most obvious, important realities are often the ones that are hardest to see and talk about. Stated as an English sentence, of course, this is just a banal platitude, but the fact is that in the day to day trenches of adult existence, banal platitudes can have a life or death importance, or so I wish to suggest to you on this dry and lovely morning.

In the way that fish take water for granted, Americans take true freedom of speech and freedom of the press for granted. It‚Äôs the culture we were born into, the air we breathe. And to my mind, the fiercest and most effective form of criticism‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâespecially political‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis mockery. Mark Twain, America‚Äôs first great (and perhaps still greatest) humorist, said, ‚ÄúAgainst the assault of laughter, nothing can stand.‚Äù

No one in Russian media mocks Vladimir Putin, lest they find themselves falling out one of Russia‚Äôs easily-fallen-out-of windows. No one in Chinese media mocks Xi Jinping. Back in 2017 the CCP went as far as to censor images of Winnie the Pooh, because Xi resembles Pooh so clearly, and people naturally find that amusing. Trump, clearly, has authoritarian instincts and desires, but US media‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâprint, web, podcasts, YouTube, social, and TV‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâhas been replete with unrelenting mockery aimed at him. There‚Äôs no better example of that than late night talk shows: Colbert on CBS, Jimmy Kimmel on ABC, Seth Meyers on NBC, Jon Stewart and his fellow hosts on The Daily Show at Comedy Central, John Oliver and Bill Maher on HBO. Vociferous, unrelenting critics of Trump, all of them. (And it works both ways: Greg Gutfield‚Äôs Gutfield! is a ratings success at 10:00pm for Fox News.)

That‚Äôs been one of the canaries I‚Äôve been monitoring in the Trump 2.0 drift-into-authoritarianism coal mine. So long as Trump is getting skewered by comedians on major TV channels nightly, in some sense, we‚Äôre doing OK.

But while our Constitution and cultural fabric protect our media from government interference, there‚Äôs no such protection from ownership interference. Trump can‚Äôt dictate what a newspaper prints‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâproven again, just last night, by The Wall Street Journal, which added significant fuel to the Epstein fire that‚Äôs rupturing MAGAland with a scoop on a dirty birthday letter Trump wrote to his friend Epstein in 2003, despite Trump trying to quash the story by directly calling Journal owner Rupert Murdoch. Trump can‚Äôt dictate who hosts late-night TV shows or censor the jokes they tell, and we still seem far from a world where Jimmy Kimmel might mysteriously ‚Äúfall‚Äù from a high window.

But the owners, they can do what they want. Jeff Bezos kiboshed The Washington Post‚Äôs already-written endorsement of Kamala Harris‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâon the cusp of the election‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand torched the paper‚Äôs previously sterling reputation of independence and journalistic integrity. Patrick Soon-Shiong has done similar to the LA Times.

CBS is owned by Paramount, and Paramount is controlled by Shari Redstone. Redstone has a deal to sell Paramount to Skydance, a company controlled by David Ellison (son of Oracle gazillionaire Larry Ellison) for $8 billion, but the deal needs approval from the FCC, and the FCC answers to Trump. That‚Äôs why CBS settled a bullshit lawsuit by Trump against 60 Minutes for $16 million. As former 60 Minutes correspondent Steve Kroft told Jon Stewart (righteously, on Paramount-owned Comedy Central) regarding the ‚Äúsettlement‚Äù: ‚ÄúThey never said, ‚ÄòWe screwed up.‚Äô They just paid the money. It was a shakedown, that‚Äôs what I call it. Some people call it extortion, that‚Äôs a legal term.‚Äù

The New York Post reported two weeks ago that the official settlement is only half the deal, however:

Shari Redstone‚Äôs Paramount received an unusual assist to settle its controversial lawsuit with President Trump, which should now clear the way for its long-awaited sale to independent studio Skydance, On The Money has learned.

Skydance boss David Ellison, the son of Trump friend and billionaire Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, stepped up and agreed that once he takes control of the Tiffany Network, currently part of Redstone‚Äôs flailing media empire, it will run between $15 million and $20 million of public service ads to promote causes supported by the president, a source with knowledge of the negotiations said.

‚ÄúThere is an anticipation of a mid-eight-figure sum that will be allocated by the network to PSA advertisements and other broadcast transmissions that support conservative causes supported by President Trump,‚Äù the source said.

It made no sense journalistically or financially for CBS to settle Trump‚Äôs lawsuit. 60 Minutes clearly did nothing ethically wrong, let alone illegal, with its editing of Kamala Harris‚Äôs interview.1 It only makes sense as a de facto payoff to Trump to help secure approval of Skydance‚Äôs acquisition of Paramount. Likewise with CBS‚Äôs decision not just to part ways with Colbert as host, but to cease production of The Late Show entirely. It makes no TV sense. The Late Show isn‚Äôt just doing OK in the ratings, it‚Äôs the top show in the 11:30 timeslot. Here‚Äôs Jed Rosenzweig, writing for LateNighter just four days ago:

As the second quarter of 2025 wrapped, late-night‚Äôs pecking order held mostly steady‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwith The Late Show with Stephen Colbert topping the 11:35 PM hour in total viewers, and Late Night with Seth Meyers leading at 12:37 AM across both key ratings metrics.

CBS‚Äôs Late Show was the only show among the nine tracked by LateNighter to draw more total viewers in Q2 than it had in the first quarter of 2025‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâalthough just barely, with the show growing its audience by 1% quarter over quarter. All told, the Stephen Colbert-hosted show averaged 2.42 million viewers across 41 first-run episodes, comfortably outpacing ABC‚Äôs Jimmy Kimmel Live (1.77 million) and NBC‚Äôs The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon (1.19 million). In the advertiser-coveted 18‚Äì49 demo, however, Kimmel surged ahead with 220,000 viewers‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâhis strongest performance in a year‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâedging out Colbert (219,000) and leaving Fallon (at 157,000) in a distant third.

At 12:37 AM, Late Night With Seth Meyers continued its quiet reign. The NBC mainstay averaged 900,000 total viewers and 111,000 in the demo across 35 episodes‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeasily topping both metrics in the late-late slot. ABC‚Äôs Nightline held second place with 810,000 total viewers and 108,000 in the demo, putting it ahead of CBS‚Äôs After Midnight, which ended its two-year run in early June with an average of 591,000 total viewers and 89,000 in the 18‚Äì49 demo.

So Colbert‚Äôs Late Show is the highest-rated overall, and effectively tied with Kimmel in the advertiser-coveted 18‚Äì49 demo.2 Like all of traditional TV, late night viewership‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand thus revenue‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâisn‚Äôt what it used to be. (For context, through the end of the 1990s and into the 2000s, Letterman and Leno each drew around 4‚Äì6 million viewers per night. Johnny Carson averaged over 10 million viewers per night in the 1970s and 80s.) CBS declaring in its announcement that ‚ÄúThis is purely a financial decision against a challenging backdrop in late night‚Äù is obvious bullshit‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand, in light of its timing, extra stinky bullshit at that. Surely the top-rated show in late night isn‚Äôt just at least profitable, but almost certainly more profitable than whatever CBS might replace it with in that time slot. (CBS sources suddenly claim The Late Show lost $40 million last year; Bill Carter isn‚Äôt buying that and neither should you.)

The TV industry has always been obsessed with ratings and obsessed with advertising revenue. I can‚Äôt recall the top-rated show in any category being cancelled. Again, it makes no TV sense. It doesn‚Äôt pass the sniff test. Back in December, regarding the Bezos-driven upheaval at The Washington Post, I wrote a piece titled ‚ÄúJournalism Requires Owners Committed to the Cause‚Äù, which title sort of says it all. The only proper way to run a serious newspaper is for the work and reputation of the newspaper itself to be the topmost priority of everyone in leadership, right up to the owner. That‚Äôs just clearly not true for Bezos. And part of it too is that the entire business of The Washington Post just doesn‚Äôt matter to Bezos. Jeff Bezos has a net worth of around $230 billion. He bought the Post from its longtime owners, the Graham family (who were owners committed to the cause) in 2013 for just $250 million. Financially, the entire Washington Post Company represents like one-thousandth of Bezos‚Äôs wealth. Trashing the paper‚Äôs reputation and the trust of its readers meant less to him than cozying up to Trump for potential trade policy favors for Amazon and rocketry deals for Blue Origin.

It‚Äôs exactly the same for David Ellison. His father, Larry Ellison, is even wealthier than Bezos, with Forbes estimating his worth above $250 billion after recent Oracle stock price gains. In normal times, with a normal US president (that is to say, not crooked), and a normal incoming buyer of a major television network (that is to say, concerned with ratings and ad revenue) it would be insane for the network to cancel the top-rated late night show just before the deal is finalized. But David Ellison doesn‚Äôt give a shit how much money CBS makes at 11:30 and doesn‚Äôt care about the three-decade legacy of The Late Show or the storied history of the theater in which it‚Äôs produced each night. Cancelling this particular hit show isn‚Äôt poison to the deal for Skydance to buy Paramount‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit‚Äôs a sweetener. I missed this at the time, but Oliver Darcy, media reporter extraordinaire, called it at Status (paywalled, alas) just over a week ago:

Jon Stewart opened Monday‚Äôs episode of The Daily Show not mincing words, calling Paramount‚Äôs settlement with Donald Trump ‚Äúshameful.‚Äù Just as he was digging in, a fake Arby‚Äôs ad suddenly appeared on screen, as if to cut him off mid-rant for criticizing Comedy Central‚Äôs parent company. ‚ÄúDid they? Son of a bitch!‚Äù Stewart exclaimed, playing along with the bit‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâyet nodding to a deeper fear that his commentary might soon be silenced amid all the corporate upheaval.

Later in the episode, Stewart continued to needle Paramount, sitting down with former 60 Minutes correspondent Steve Kroft for a candid and unsparing conversation. Kroft described the settlement in clear terms: ‚ÄúIt was a shakedown.‚Äù Inside ‚ÄúThe Daily Show,‚Äù I‚Äôm told staffers have taken pride that Stewart showed once again he is willing to stand up to powerful interests, even if it potentially risks his future employment. And while they may not yet know it, inside certain power circles, there is an open question: How much longer will Stewart have this platform?

Indeed, the reality is that the ground under not only Stewart, but also Stephen Colbert, is shifting fast. Skydance, led by Larry and David Ellison, now believes its merger with Paramount will close in the next several weeks, I‚Äôm told. Much of the attention has focused on how the Ellisons will reshape 60 Minutes and CBS News. We first reported that David Ellison met with Bari Weiss about a possible role at CBS News, and it is clear the Ellisons want to rid the network of what they see as a liberal taint. But little has been said about the futures of Colbert and Stewart, who have been two of Trump‚Äôs most consistent comedic antagonists, under the new corporate leadership. [...]

As one media insider put it to me this week, ‚ÄúWhat better gift could [the Ellisons] give Trump than to get rid of Colbert and Stewart?‚Äù

The first shoe dropped at CBS last night. TV-wise, it‚Äôd be crazy for Paramount to drop Jon Stewart too. But dropping Colbert is even crazier, and they already did that. It‚Äôs not tyranny or the threat of state violence that is taking The Late Show With Stephen Colbert off the air, but rather oligarchy and unchecked cronyism and corruption. The breathtaking abdication we‚Äôre seeing at CBS‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfirst news with 60 Minutes, now commentary and humor with The Late Show‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâsignals a decidedly American descent into curse-not-the-king mass media acquiescence to Trump‚Äôs authoritarian hostility to criticism and dissent.

Postscript

Here‚Äôs Trump on his blog this morning, heralding the news with his usual grace, equanimity, and factual accuracy:

I absolutely love that Colbert‚Äô [sic] got fired. His talent was even less than his ratings. I hear Jimmy Kimmel is next. Has even less talent than Colbert! Greg Gutfeld is better than all of them combined, including the Moron on NBC who ruined the once great Tonight Show.

I will admit that it‚Äôs kind of funny that he didn‚Äôt even deign to address Fallon by name, especially since Fallon is the one who did the most to normalize Trump‚Äôs aberrant candidacy in 2016.

  1. If any interview with a 2024 presidential candidate was edited deceptively to help the candidate in question, it was this Fox News interview with Trump, which resurfaced this month amidst the Jeffrey Epstein imbroglio. Fox grossly truncated a glaringly evasive answer from Trump regarding whether, if re-elected, he would release all DOJ files related to Epstein. ↩︎

  2. Which hurts slightly to write about, insofar as I‚Äôve aged out of the demo personally. Now I‚Äôm a non-coveted TV watcher‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut one who‚Äôs skipped all the commercials on late night shows for 25 years anyway. ↩︎Ô∏é

entry.title: Rare Earth Magnet Maker MP Materials Is Having a Big Week
entry.content:
Spencer Kimball, reporting for CNBC one week ago:

The Defense Department will become the largest shareholder in rare earth miner MP Materials after agreeing to buy $400 million of its preferred stock, the company said Thursday.

MP Materials owns the only operational rare earth mine in the U.S. at Mountain Pass, California, about 60 miles outside Las Vegas. Proceeds from the Pentagon investment will be used to expand MP‚Äôs rare earths processing capacity and magnet production, the company said. Shares of MP Materials soared about 50% to close at $45.23. Its market capitalization grew to $7.4 billion, an increase of about $2.5 billion from the previous trading session. [...]

MP Materials CEO James Litinsky described the Pentagon investment as a public-private partnership that will speed the buildout of an end-to-end rare earth magnet supply chain in the U.S.

‚ÄúI want to be very clear, this is not a nationalization,‚Äù Litinsky told CNBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúSquawk on the Street‚Äù on Thursday. ‚ÄúWe remain a thriving public company. We now have a great new partner in our economically largest shareholder, DoD, but we still control our company. We control our destiny. We‚Äôre shareholder driven.‚Äù U.S. miners are facing a unique threat from ‚ÄúChinese mercantilism,‚Äù Litinsky said. The Pentagon investment in MP could serve as a model for similar deals with other U.S. companies, the CEO said.

This news caught my eye when Taegan Goddard linked to it from Political Wire yesterday (quipping, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm old enough to remember when this was called ‚Äòsocialism‚Äô‚Äù), because yesterday MP Materials landed a $500 million deal from Apple. Apple Newsroom:

Today Apple announced a new commitment of $500 million with MP Materials, the only fully integrated rare earth producer in the United States. With this multiyear deal, Apple is committed to buying American-made rare earth magnets developed at MP Materials‚Äô flagship Independence facility in Fort Worth, Texas. The two companies will also work together to establish a cutting-edge rare earth recycling line in Mountain Pass, California, and develop novel magnet materials and innovative processing technologies to enhance magnet performance. The commitment is part of Apple‚Äôs pledge to spend more than $500 billion in the U.S. over the next four years, and builds on the company‚Äôs long history of investment in American innovation, advanced manufacturing, and next-generation recycling technologies. [...]

When complete, the new recycling facility in Mountain Pass, California will enable MP Materials to take in recycled rare earth feedstock‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâincluding material from used electronics and post-industrial scrap‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand reprocess it for use in Apple products. For nearly five years, Apple and MP Materials have been piloting advanced recycling technology that enables recycled rare earth magnets to be processed into material that meets Apple‚Äôs exacting standards for performance and design. The companies will continue to innovate together to improve magnet production, as well as end-of-life recovery.

Apple pioneered the use of recycled rare earth elements in consumer electronics, first introducing them in the Taptic Engine of iPhone 11 in 2019. Today, nearly all magnets across Apple devices are made with 100 percent recycled rare earth elements.

The timing of these two announcements could be purely coincidental, but I can‚Äôt help but wonder if both moves were fueled by concerns about China cornering the market on rare earth magnets. Conversely, I wonder if this deal (and promotion of it) from Apple is aimed just to placate the Trump administration. A $500 million commitment is surely a big deal for MP Materials. It‚Äôs not that big a deal for Apple. What makes it interesting is that it‚Äôs with an American company.

If you find yourself walking down the street in the 1980s and you see someone coming who prefers the VIC-20 to the Apple II, cross to the other side of the street. (That said, the VIC-20 really was revolutionary. It was by far the most affordable home computer anyone had ever seen at that point. It was laughably underpowered ‚Ä¶ but: it was only $300! They sold a million of ‚Äôem.)

Snell takes issue (correctly!) with Drew Saur‚Äôs framing of the Apple II as ‚Äúcorporate‚Äù. As Snell points out, Commodore was founded by a suit‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâApple was founded by two guys whose first collaboration was making phone-phreaking blue boxes.

But a more pertinent point was made by Dr. Drang on Mastodon:

I don‚Äôt want to get on the bad side of @gruber and @jsnell, but when they say the Commodore 64 cost $600, that‚Äôs misleading. Yes, it cost $600 when it was released, but its price dropped quickly. By the time I bought one in late ‚Äô83 or early ‚Äô84, it was selling for $200 at Kmart. To recognize that it was a great computer for the price, you have to know what that price really was.

When I wrote the other day that the C64 cost $600, it didn‚Äôt jibe with my memory. But my thinking is too set in the ways of Apple, where a computer debuts at a price and then stays at that price. A price around $200 is more what I remember for the C64, at a time when a bare-bones IIe cost $1,400. Inflation-adjusted, $200 in 1984 is about $620 today, and $1,400 is about $4,300. That‚Äôs why so many more kids of my era got their parents to spring for a Commodore 64 but not an Apple II. They were rivals in some sense, but really, the Apple II was a different class of computer, and cost nearly an order of magnitude more. Inflation-adjusted, it‚Äôs very similar to the difference in both price and capabilities of the Meta Quest versus Vision Pro.

(Me, I didn‚Äôt own a computer until I went to college. My parents wouldn‚Äôt buy me one because they feared if they did, I‚Äôd never leave the house. I resented it at the time, but in hindsight, they might have been right. I didn‚Äôt fight too hard because we had an Atari 2600 and a generous budget for game cartridges. Plus, my grade school had a few Apple IIe‚Äôs (alongside a bunch of cheap TI-99/4A‚Äôs), and my middle/high school had an entire lab of Apple IIe‚Äôs and IIc‚Äôs.)

entry.title: Elmore Leonard‚Äôs Perfect Pitch
entry.content:
Anthony Lane, in a crackerjack piece for The New Yorker on the writing and work of Elmore Leonard:

So, when does Leonard become himself? Is it possible to specify the moment, or the season, when he crosses the border? I would nominate ‚ÄúThe Big Bounce,‚Äù from 1969‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich, by no coincidence, is the first novel of his to be set in the modern age. As the prose calms down, something quickens in the air, and the plainest words and deeds make easy music: ‚ÄúThey discussed whether beer was better in bottles or cans, and then which was better, bottled or draft, and both agreed, finally, that it didn‚Äôt make a hell of a lot of difference. Long as it was cold.‚Äù

What matters here is what isn‚Äôt there. Grammatically, by rights, we ought to have an ‚ÄúAs‚Äù or a ‚ÄúSo‚Äù before ‚Äúlong.‚Äù If the beer drinkers were talking among themselves, however, or to themselves, they wouldn‚Äôt bother with such nicety, and Leonard heeds their example; he does them the honor of flavoring his registration of their chatter with that perfect hint of them. The technical term for this trick, as weary students of literature will recall, is style indirect libre, or free indirect discourse. It has a noble track record, with Jane Austen and Flaubert as front-runners, but seldom has it proved so democratically wide-ranging‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânot just libre but liberating, too, as Leonard tunes in to regular citizens. He gets into their heads, their palates, and their plans for the evening. Listen to a guy named Moran, in ‚ÄúCat Chaser‚Äù (1982), watching Monday-night football and trying to decide ‚Äúwhether he should have another beer and fry a steak or go to Vesuvio‚Äôs on Federal Highway for spaghetti marinara and eat the crisp breadsticks with hard butter, Jesus, and have a bottle of red with it, the house salad ... or get the chicken cacciatore and slock the bread around in the gravy ...‚Äù

The ellipses are Leonard‚Äôs, or, rather, they are Moran‚Äôs musings, reproduced by Leonard as a kind of Morse code. We join in with the dots. But it‚Äôs the ‚ÄúJesus‚Äù that does the work, yielding up a microsecond of salivation, and inviting us to slock around in the juice of the character‚Äôs brain.

The genius in the second example is the verb choice: slock. There are dozens of verbs that could have worked there, but none better.

Leonard is probably tops on the list of authors whose work I love, but of which I haven‚Äôt read nearly as much as I should. There are novelists who are good at creating (and voicing) original vivid characters, novelists who are good at plot, and novelists who are just great at writing. Leonard hits the trifecta.

Last year, retro computing YouTuber Christian ‚ÄúPeri Fractic‚Äù Simpson bought licensed the branding rights and some of the IP belonging to Commodore (which rights have been transferred five times since the original company went bankrupt in 1994). Last week they launched their first product:

This is the first real Commodore computer in over 30 years, and it‚Äôs picked up a few new tricks.

Not an emulator. Not a PC. Retrogaming heaven in three dimensions: silicon, nostalgia, and light. Powered by a FPGA recreation of the original motherboard, wrapped in glowing game-reactive LEDs (or classic beige of course).

Via Ernie Smith, who has been following this saga thoughtfully.

This is, no question, a fun and cool project, and I hope it succeeds wildly. But personally, the Commodore 64 holds almost no nostalgic value for me. The Commodore 64‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich came out in 1982, when I was 9‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâalways struck me as cheap-feeling and inelegant. Like using some weird computer from the Soviet Union. Just look at its keyboard. It‚Äôs got a bunch of odd keys, like ‚ÄúRun Stop‚Äù and ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù, and all sorts of drawing-related glyphs (used when programming) printed on the sides of the keycaps. Now compare that to the keyboards from the Apple II Plus (1979), which has just one weird key, ‚ÄúREPT‚Äù (for Repeat‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâyou needed to press and hold REPT to get other keys to repeat, which, admittedly, seems inexplicable in hindsight), and to the Apple IIe (1983), which has no weird keys and whose keyboard looks remarkably modern lo these 42 intervening years.

That said, while both systems came with 64 kilobytes of RAM, the Apple IIe cost $1,400 when it debuted (~$4,600 today, inflation adjusted); the Commodore 64 cost $600 (~$2,000 today). Some things haven‚Äôt changed about the computer industry in my lifetime.

The most interesting computers Commodore ever made, by far, were the Amigas. The Amiga brand and IP were cleaved from Commodore long ago, and alas, the new Commodore doesn‚Äôt have them. But they‚Äôve expressed interest in buying them. Something like this Commodore 64 Ultimate but for an Amiga‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânow that might get me to reach for my credit card.

entry.summary: Post-Williams, Apple‚Äôs operations will clearly remain under excellent, experienced leadership under Sabih Khan. But the company will be left with its design teams reporting directly to Cook, leaving it less clear whose taste, [ultimately], is steering the work of the company into the future.
entry.content:
Apple Newsroom, this afternoon:

Apple today announced Jeff Williams will transition his role as chief operating officer later this month to Sabih Khan, Apple‚Äôs senior vice president of Operations as part of a long-planned succession. Williams will continue reporting to Apple CEO Tim Cook and overseeing Apple‚Äôs world class design team and Apple Watch alongside the company‚Äôs Heath initiatives. Apple‚Äôs design team will then transition to reporting directly to Cook after Williams retires late in the year.

Apple‚Äôs executive ranks have been so remarkably stable for so long that any change feels surprising. But Williams is 62 years old and has been at Apple for 27 years. Tim Cook is 64, and Khan is 58. The whole thing seems amicable and orderly, and thus completely in line with everything we know about Williams‚Äôs and Cook‚Äôs seemingly similar personalities. After a long and successful career, Apple‚Äôs COO is retiring and his longtime lieutenant is being promoted to replace him this month. Apple‚Äôs operations aren‚Äôt just world-class, they‚Äôre almost certainly world-best. Even their leadership transitions are operationally smooth. Khan was promoted in 2019 to the title of senior vice president of operations. Williams was promoted from that title (SVP of operations) to COO in 2015, four years after Cook took over as CEO from Steve Jobs.

But that‚Äôs the operations part.

What‚Äôs intriguing about the announcement is the design part‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa functional area where, especially on the software side, Apple‚Äôs current stature is subject to much debate. While Williams is staying on until ‚Äúlate in the year‚Äù to continue his other responsibilities‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâWatch, Health, and serving as the senior executive Apple‚Äôs design teams report to‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâKhan isn‚Äôt taking over those roles when Williams leaves. And so by the end of the year, Apple‚Äôs design teams will go from reporting to Williams to reporting directly to Tim Cook.

I‚Äôve long found it curious, if not downright dubious, that Apple‚Äôs design leaders have reported to Williams ever since it was announced in 2019 (the very same day that Khan was promoted to SVP of operations) that Jony Ive would be stepping down as chief design officer and leaving Apple to found the (as-yet-unnamed) design firm LoveFrom. Williams had no background in design at all. Apple‚Äôs design teams reporting to an operations executive makes no more sense than it would for Apple‚Äôs operations teams to report to, say, Alan Dye. Well, maybe it made a little more sense than that‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâhaving design report to Williams sort of felt like a way to give Williams experience across the breadth of the company in the case that he ever needed to step in to replace Cook as CEO, either temporarily or permanently, as Cook was asked to for Jobs.

But when that was announced in 2019, I expected it to be temporary, while Apple took its time to properly identify a new senior design leader. Someone with, you know, design leadership experience, and strong opinions about and deep knowledge of the craft of design. That was six years ago, and Apple has seemingly made not one move toward naming a new chief design officer or (the more likely title) SVP of design. It seems like time for that now.

I get the impression‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfrom multiple sources‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat overseeing, not leading, is in fact exactly the right word for Williams‚Äôs role regarding design since 2019. Williams oversaw design the same way Tim Cook, ultimately, oversees everything the company does. It was in no way a token role. Williams was there. He asked insightful questions about product designs and experiences. But he didn‚Äôt push back or offer opinions. There‚Äôs much to like about Liquid Glass, for example, but there‚Äôs also a lot of shitty UI functionality and just plain bad design that makes you wonder how numerous aspects even escaped the drawing board, let alone made their way into the WWDC keynote and various OS 26 betas. Looking back at the last six years of Apple design‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâhardware, software, packaging, architecture‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI detect not one fingerprint of style or taste that belongs to Jeff Williams. Given that Williams is not a designer, that‚Äôs not a surprise. But it‚Äôs a problem for the company if its products don‚Äôt ultimately have a distinctive voice.

I‚Äôm of the mind that, in hindsight, it was a mistake for Jony Ive to bring HI (software human interface design) under the same roof as ID (hardware industrial design). That arrangement made sense for Ive‚Äôs unique role in the company, and the unique period in the wake of Steve Jobs‚Äôs too-young demise. But it might have ultimately made Ive more difficult to replace than Steve Jobs. Williams‚Äôs combination of authority, mild-mannered-ness, and equanimity might have made him uniquely suited to either finding another Ive-like design leader whom all sides could have agreed to (even if begrudgingly), or, perhaps, to the task of unwinding the intermingling of HI and ID that occurred during the Jony-as-CDO era. But neither of those things happened.

Post-Williams, Apple‚Äôs operations will clearly remain under excellent, experienced leadership under Sabih Khan. But the company will be left with its design teams reporting directly to Cook‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwho is three years older than Williams. Six years after Jony Ive‚Äôs departure, today‚Äôs announcements leave it less clear than ever whose taste, ultimately, is steering the work of the company into the future. Perhaps, I hope, Williams is staying until the end of the year to help answer that question.

entry.summary: I can see the argument that Apple‚Äôs answer is ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs potentially confusing for many users‚Äù. But I can‚Äôt see the argument that the answer is ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs potentially confusing for many users, but only if they‚Äôre trying to buy in-app content or subscriptions, but not confusing at all if they‚Äôre trying to buy, say, movie tickets.‚Äù
entry.content:
MG Siegler, on Threads last week:

We‚Äôre already beyond ridiculous with the full-on ad assault from Apple as everyone is well aware by now. But the wild thing here‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâin this full screen pop-up in the Apple TV app‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis that it‚Äôs not in-app but links out to the web to pay?!

At least here in the US, if you just opened the TV app on iOS 18 last week, you were presented with this full-screen ad (replete with all those dumb ¬Æ‚Äôs, despite Apple‚Äôs ads for the same thing in the App Store omitting them).

There were two buttons to choose from: ‚ÄúNot Now‚Äù and ‚ÄúBuy Tickets ‚ÜóÔ∏é‚Äù. If you tapped the ‚ÄúBuy Tickets ‚ÜóÔ∏é‚Äù button, boom, you just jumped to the F1 The Movie website in your default browser. Kyle Alden, on Threads:

That‚Äôs weird, Apple‚Äôs new full screen F1 ad in the TV app links out to the browser to compete the transaction, but for some reason doesn‚Äôt include any full screen interstitials warning of the big scary web, nor a confirmation dialog that it would open in the browser? Must be an oversight.

The hypocrisy isn‚Äôt that Apple didn‚Äôt show a full-screen scare sheet for this link-out to the web. It‚Äôs that they require other developers, who are doing it to sell digital content, to show a scare sheet/confirmation.

One of the subtle differences with this particular promotion is that buying movie tickets is not ‚Äúdigital content‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeven if they‚Äôre just passes in Apple Wallet or saved QR codes in an app like Fandango. You‚Äôre purchasing a real-world experience, so it‚Äôs not eligible for Apple‚Äôs In-App Purchase (IAP) system. This is why when you buy theater tickets in the Fandango app, Fandango charges your credit or debit card directly. Same when you pay for rides in Uber or Lyft. It‚Äôs really subtle for something like a movie. Pay for a movie to watch on your TV at home? That‚Äôs a digital purchase. Pay for a movie to watch in a theater? Not a digital purchase.

I understand the distinction between digital content (that‚Äôs consumed on your Apple device) and real-world goods and experiences (even if you pay for them in apps on your Apple device). But how many iPhone users understand this distinction? Like, if you polled 1,000 U.S. iPhone users who (a) purchase in-game content in games like Candy Crush, and (b) hail rides in Uber or Lyft, what percentage of those iPhone users do you think could give a coherent answer as to why their in-game purchases must use Apple‚Äôs IAP system, and why Uber not only doesn‚Äôt use IAP to charge for rides, but is not allowed to use IAP for that? I‚Äôd bet fewer than 1 percent. (I‚Äôd also bet that fewer than 1 percent care, which is why they don‚Äôt know.)

Is it inherently confusing to have a button in an app that jumps you out of the app to your default web browser (probably Safari, especially for people who might be confused) to complete a transaction, without a scare sheet or even a confirmation alert? I can see the argument that Apple‚Äôs answer is ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs potentially confusing for many users‚Äù. But I can‚Äôt see the argument that the answer is ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs potentially confusing for many users, but only if they‚Äôre trying to buy in-app content or subscriptions, but not confusing at all if they‚Äôre trying to buy, say, movie tickets.‚Äù

entry.content:
Let‚Äôs start with Apple‚Äôs own announcement at Apple Developer News:

The European Commission has required Apple to make a series of additional changes under the Digital Markets Act:

Communication and Promotion of Offers

  • Today, we‚Äôre introducing updated terms that let developers with apps in the European Union storefronts of the App Store communicate and promote offers for purchase of digital goods or services available at a destination of their choice. The destination can be a website, alternative app marketplace, or another app, and can be accessed outside the app or within the app via a web view or native experience.
  • App Store apps that communicate and promote offers for digital goods or services will be subject to new business terms for those transactions‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâan initial acquisition fee, store services fee, and for apps on the StoreKit External Purchase Link Entitlement (EU) Addendum, the Core Technology Commission (CTC). The CTC reflects value Apple provides developers through ongoing investments in the tools, technologies, and services that enable them to build and share innovative apps with users. [...]

Update to Business Terms for Apps in the European Union

  • By January 1, 2026, Apple plans to move to a single business model in the EU for all developers.   • Apps currently under the Alternative Terms Addendum for Apps in the EU continue to be subject only to the CTF until the transition to the CTC is fully implemented next year. At that time, qualifying transactions will be subject to the CTC, and the CTF will no longer apply. Additional details regarding this transition will be provided at a later date.

Amongst other policy and API changes, Apple also announced a new, seemingly simplified, experience on iOS/iPadOS for installing apps and alternative app marketplaces in the EU.

As for the other policy changes, here‚Äôs Jason Snell‚Äôs summary, which I think captures the gist as well as possible:

Tiered App Store fees. For today‚Äôs full-service App Store, developers will now pay 13% on sales, reduced to 10% for Small Business Program members. Or developers can opt into ‚ÄúTier One‚Äù, which comes with a 5% fee but does not support a raft of App Store features we‚Äôve come to expect, like automatic app updates, App Store promotions, placement in search suggestions, ratings and reviews on product listings (!), and more.

Core Technology Commission. Apple is going to move all developers over to a new tax called the Core Technology Commission, in which developers who opt to sell apps outside the App Store will pay 5% of sales made through in-app promotions. The ‚Ç¨0.50-per-install Core Technology Fee will be dropped as of January 1.

Free linking. Developers can promote offers broadly, are no longer limited to a single static URL without tracking parameters, and can freely design the interfaces for those links and promotions.

New business terms. Developers have to pay a 2% fee for digital goods and services purchased by new users for the first six months after a user first downloads an app; members of the Small Business Program don‚Äôt have to pay this fee.

And here‚Äôs Chance Miller‚Äôs summary at 9to5Mac, which includes the following statement from Apple (which statement was provided to me, as well):

‚ÄúThe European Commission is requiring Apple to make a series of additional changes to the App Store. We disagree with this outcome and plan to appeal.‚Äù

The new fee structure is undeniably convoluted, and I think downright confusing. Seemingly no one can figure out exactly what commissions apps that use alternative payments or distribution are going to pay. It‚Äôs a natural consequence that an overly complicated law (the DMA) has resulted in an ever-more-complicated set of guidelines and policies (from Apple): byzantine compliance with a byzantine law.

Because it‚Äôs so complicated and hard to understand, it‚Äôs difficult even to summarize with a headline describing what‚Äôs new. Even if you understand it enough to just want to express anger at Apple for spiteful compliance and greed, it‚Äôs hard to sum up why you‚Äôre angry in a succinct headline or tweet.

The bottom line, as I understand it, is the following (but I could be wrong about some of this1‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâif I am, let me know, and I‚Äôll try to correct it):

  • Developers who just do the simplest thing possible‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâdistribute through the App Store and process all payments using Apple‚Äôs IAP‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwill continue to pay the same commissions, 30% by default, or 15% for Small Business Program developers and recurring subscriptions after the first year. Of course this is what Apple would prefer developers do.

  • Big developers, distributing through the App Store but processing their own payments, will still owe Apple a commission of around 20% on non-IAP purchases: 13% for ‚Äústore services‚Äù, 5% for the new Core Technology Commission (replacing the ‚Ç¨0.50 per-download Core Technology Fee), and 2% for ‚Äúinitial acquisition‚Äù. Small Developer Program members and recurring subscriptions after the first year pay 15%‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâno ‚Äúinitial acquisition fee‚Äù and a reduced ‚Äústore services‚Äù fee of 10%. But everyone‚Äôs on the hook for the 5% CTC.

  • Apps distributed through the App Store can pay a reduced rate of 5% for ‚Äústore services‚Äù (down from 13%) by opting into a reduced ‚ÄúTier 1‚Äù. Rather than this ‚ÄúTier 1‚Äù being an appealing choice for any developers, I think the point of it is for Apple to assert that those App Store features justify 8 percent of Apple‚Äôs commission on purchases: automatic software updates, reviews and ratings, surfacing through search for anything other than an exact name match, and a whole lot more.

  • One consequence of the ‚Ç¨0.50 per-download Core Technology Fee (CTF) being replaced by a 5% Core Technology Commission (CTC) is that there will no longer be a penalty for small developers who have a free-to-download app that hits over one million EU downloads. That was a legitimate problem with the CTF‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâan app with 5 million EU downloads would owe Apple ‚Ç¨2 million for the CTF, but might be generating far less than that (or even nothing at all) in revenue. But another consequence of switching to the CTC from the CTF is that super-popular apps from super-big companies that don‚Äôt sell digital goods from their apps will continue to pay nothing at all. E.g. unless Meta starts selling digital goods from within their apps, they‚Äôll continue to pay nothing at all to Apple for zillion-download apps like Instagram, Facebook, and WhatsApp. That was a shortcoming with the App Store‚Äôs model that the CTF was designed to correct.

  • All of this additional complication is, I believe, just for apps distributed through the App Store. Feel free to blame Apple as much as you want for spiteful compliance (especially when it comes to payments made on the web, from links in apps), but part of this is on the European Commission for demanding not only that Apple allow apps to be distributed outside the App Store (which is somewhat reasonable), but also for requiring Apple to allow outside payments for apps distributed through the App Store. Apps and games distributed through alternative EU app marketplaces or web downloads are only on the hook for the 5% CTC (by the end of the year, when it replaces the CTF). But there is no free lunch‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâiOS apps and games distributed outside the App Store that require a purchase, or offer digital content for sale, must pay the 5% CTC.

There are a lot of people who think what Apple is ‚Äúsupposed‚Äù to do is collect no commission or fees at all on anything other than IAP from apps and games that are distributed through the App Store. That Apple should collect no commission or fees from apps distributed outside the App Store, nor any commission or fees from apps in the App Store that offer their own payment processing‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand, thus, that Apple should set their own IAP commission accordingly, as something akin to Stripe or PayPal, in the single-digit percentage range. That‚Äôs obviously not in Apple‚Äôs interest. But it‚Äôs also not what the European Commission has suggested the DMA demands.

That‚Äôd be really weird, insofar as it would mean that developers in the EU get an 80/20 split for App Store distribution + IAP, but apps everywhere else in the world still get 70/30 for the same thing. That doesn‚Äôt make sense unless there‚Äôs another shoe to drop, and Apple is going to reduce IAP to 80/20 worldwide soon. (Which would be a great move on Apple‚Äôs part‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâsomething that would actually earn them back some developer goodwill.) ↩︎
